I understand and embrace the role of the identity thief. 

The most satisfying part? Watching the pieces fall into place, knowing I’ve turned their life upside down. It’s not just about the money or the power—it’s the *weight* of helplessness I see in their eyes when they realize what’s been taken. I remember how it felt when *my* identity was stolen—like being erased, like your entire existence is now a lie. Now, I get to make them feel that. 

When I open a new credit card in their name, or rack up debt they’ll spend years clawing out of, I’m not just punishing them—I’m proving a point. The system failed me, so why should I care if it fails them too? Every victim I target is a mirror. They see their own vulnerability reflected back, and I make sure it cracks under the pressure. 

The real thrill is when they start to unravel—when they can’t sleep, when they beg for help from banks and cops who shrug them off. That’s when I know I’ve done it right. They’ll spend nights staring at their walls, wondering how someone could do this, while I’m laughing in the dark, knowing I’m the one who taught them how to play the game. 

It’s poetic, really. I took everything from them, just like they took everything from me. And the best part? They’ll never know it was me.
